captions.text:
We're planning to bring
in some experts from the
oceanographic institute.
know how l earn a livin'.

l'll catch this bird foryou,
but it ain't gonna be easy.

A little shakin'
a little tenderi'zin'

And we gotta do it quick.
Gotta bring back the tourists.

That'll put all your businesses
on a payin' basis.

But it's not
gonna be pleasant !

l value my neck a lot more than
three thousand bucks, Chief.

but l'll catch him
and kill him forten.

You gotta
make up your minds.

Gonna stay alive and ante up,
or gonna play it cheap ?

Be on welfare
the whole winter.

l don't want
no volunteers, no mates.

There's too many captains
on this island.

For that
you get the head,

the tail,
the whole damn thing.

title: The Head, the Tail, the Whole Damn Thing - Jaws (3/10) Movie CLIP (1975) HD

comments.author: Krystal Harwood

comments.text:
Great scene in Jaws. Amity has called a meeting realising now they have a 
serious shark problem after the death of a young boy. Brody is explaining 
what's going to happen and the beaches were going to be shut temporarily. 
But then Quint interrupts and tells them he will hunt and kill the shark 
for them. There's a $3000 bounty on its head but Quint wants $10,000 to get 
the job done. For that he says they get him. The head, the tail, the whole 
damn thing!﻿

comments.text:
+daustin8888 It was altered heavily for the film, yes. Actually, I think 
it's a very rare case of the film being better & an improvement on the 
book. The film is much scarier.


Another good example is The Godfather: the book often feels like it was 
written at a grade school level. Great story, badly written. Coppola 
improved the telling of the story greatly.
comments.author: tommyt1971

comments.text: +tommyt1971 the book is almost a completely different story
comments.author: daustin8888

comments.text:
Funny you should put it that way! In the novel, there's a huge amount of 
animosity btwn Brody & Hooper. Near the end of the battle with the shark, 
(SPOILER warning!!!!) the shark eats Hooper. When the shark pops up with 
Hooper in it's mouth, Brody shoots at it & WHOOPS!!! hits Hooper in the 
neck!!

comments.author: mts ts

comments.text:
When did he say he was Irish? He died in Ireland sure, maybe had an 
affection for Ireland, but I don't recall reading any renunciation of his 
being English (we're not talking St Patrick here ;). Despite what some 
would say, being English is nothing to be ashamed of. I'm left puzzled as 
to why anyone would deny being English to pretend to be Irish anyway, 
particularly a brilliant man like Shaw who seemed above such posing . I 
wonder if Donald Pleasence was pretending to be Irish as well? Oliver Reed? 
Hmmm....

comments.text:
I think THIS is the perfect introduction of Quint. Spielberg originally 
wanted to introduce him in a movie theatre, laughing his head off at Moby 
Dick with crappy effects. But Moby Dick movie's actor/owner didn't want 
Spielberg showing the movie because of he was ashamed of it and didn't want 
it to be seen again. IMO, this is better anyway.
comments.author: Jason Fox

comments.text:
what was his contribution? did you not notice the relationship between him 
and shaw's character? they contrast each-other, with roy right in the 
middle. hes a sheriff trying to save his town, he has a crazy sailor on one 
end, and a bookish academic type on the other. you cant have quint without 
hooper. it would be a flat story,as great an actor as shaw is, dreyfuss 
very much held his own. he added subtle comedy as well. besides, who would 
shaw yell "hoopa!" at?

comments.text:
What Quint was eating ? Who cares. Okay then. Quint was eating crackers 
comprising blue gills or tommycocks. As a matter of fact, they only 
insisted on Robert Shaw snacking o something in this scene, presumably 
because Spielberg wanted a correlation between Quint's description of the 
shark snacking on some hapless human victim, and the sene itself.
